titlestmt.title: Letter to [John Linnell?], 11 October 1819 : electronic edition

objinfo.numberleaves: 1Blake's letter is on one side (object 1) of a single leaf, which was folded to form a packet. The letter appears on what would have been the interior of the folded packet (object 1). On the reverse side of object 1 five lines of unclear text are inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand: "Mr. H[eaphy]. was brought up / as an Engraver but / [became & An artist?] / in water color / He died 1835". This inscription can be accessed as a Supplemental View on the Object View Page.
objinfo.addressee: Unnamed, probably John Linnell; Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 1650), Erdman (page 773), and Keynes (*Letters*, page 146) also suggest Linnell as the unnamed addressee.

provenance.name: Harry Ransom Center, The University of Texas at Austin
provenance.note: Sold at Sotheby's, 3-4 June 1907, lot 385 (£10.15s. to B. F. Stevens); in the collection of Goodspeed's in Boston by 1925; later in the collection of George C. Smith, Jr.; sold after Smith’s death at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, New York, 2 November 1938, lot 7 ($45 to Sessler); later in the collection of Moncure Biddle; sold by Biddle at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 29 April 1952, lot 117 ($100 to Schwartz); acquired by Dr. E. Hanley of Bradford, Pennsylvania; sold by Dr. Hanley in 1965 to the University of Texas.

repository.institution: Harry Ransom Center, The University of Texas at Austin

desc.objtitle: I will have the Pleasure of meeting you, Object 1

objnote.p: Blake's letter is on one side (object 1) of a single leaf, which was folded to form a packet. The letter appears on what would have been the interior of the folded packet (object 1). On the reverse side of object 1 five lines of unclear text are inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand: "Mr. H[eaphy]. was brought up / as an Engraver but / [became & An artist?] / in water color / He died 1835". This inscription can be accessed as a Supplemental View on the Object View Page.
In the top right corner, "CND=" is inscribed in pencil in an unknown hand.

lg.l: I will have the Pleasure of meeting
you on Thursday at 12 OClock it is quite as
Convenient to me as any other day. It appears
to me that neither Time nor Place. can make any
real difference as to perfect Independence of
Judgment. & If it is more Convenient to
Mr Heaphy for us to meet at his House let
us accomodate him in what is Indifferent but
not at all in what is of weight & moment to
our Decision. hoping that I may meet you
